"ent1": soil is referred to as regolith
"rel": or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically
"ent2": the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

"label":
The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy

Reagents are distinguished from instruments or devices that also participate in scientific techniques by the fact that reagents are chemical or biological in nature and necessarily participate in or have parts that participate in some chemical interaction or reaction during their intended participation in some technique.  By contrast
"ent1": instruments do not participate in a chemical reaction/interaction during the technique.

"label": Reagents are distinguished from study subjects/evaluants in that study subjects and evaluants are that about which conclusions are drawn and knowledge is sought in an investigation - while reagents
"rel": are not.  It should be noted
column5: that reagent and study subject/evaluant roles can be borne by instances of the same type of material entity - but a given instance will realize only one of these roles in the execution of a given assay or technique. For example
column6: taq polymerase can bear a reagent role or an evaluant role.  In a DNA sequencing assay aimed at generating sequence data about some plasmid
column7: the reagent role of the taq polymerase is realized. In an assay to evaluate the quality of the taq polymerase itself
column8: the evaluant/study subject role of the taq is realized
column9: but not the reagent role since the taq is the subject about which data is generated.

"label": In regard to the statement that reagents are 'distinct' from the specified outputs of a technique
"ent1": note that a reagent may be incorporated into a material output of a technique
"rel": as long as the IDENTITY of this output is distinct from that of the bearer of the reagent role.  For example
"ent2": dNTPs input into a PCR are reagents that become part of the material output of this technique
column5: but this output has a new identity (ie that of a 'nucleic acid molecule') that is distinct from the identity of the dNTPs that comprise it.  Similarly
column6: a biotin molecule input into a cell labeling technique are reagents that become part of the specified output
column7: but the identity of the output is that of some modified cell specimen which shares identity with the input unmodified cell specimen
column8: and not with the biotin label. Thus
column9: we see that an important criteria of 'reagent-ness' is that it is a facilitator
column10: and not the primary focus of an investigation or material processing technique (ie not the specified subject/evaluant about which knowledge is sought
column11: or the specified output material of the technique)."

"label": "The concept of a 'secondary cultured cell population' covers cell lines as well as cultured cell populations more immediately derived from a primary culture which have yet to achieve adequate genetic stability and compositional homogeneity to be considered a cell line. The extent of the collection of cells in a 'secondary cultured cell population' is restricted only in that all cell members must share a propagation history (ie be derived through a common lineage of passages from an initial culture).  Secondary cultured cell populations can be under active culture
"ent1": stored in a quiescent state for future use

"label": "1. The term 'line' is used when a culture has undergone an intentional experimental process to establish a more uniform and stable population of cells (see 'establishing cell line'). This will require one or more passages
"ent1": but may involve additional selection processes. Through such passaging and/or selection processes
"rel": the resulting 'line' attains some level of genetic stability and compositional homogeneity which is typically absent in primary cultures. Because of their relative homogeneity
"ent2": 'lines' are capable of being characterized and stably propagated over a period of time. A *new* cell line can be "established" not only through the passaging/selection of a primary culture
column5: but also through experimental modifications of existing lines (e.g. immortalization
column7: drug selection for a resistant subset
column8: etc.).  As defined here
column9: 'cell line' can refer to a population of cells in active culture
column10: applied experimentally
column11: or stored in a quescent state for future use.

"label": 2. The definitional criteria provided here for the 'cell line' class demarcates populations that represent what researchers actually use in the practice of science - e.g. as inputs to culturing
"rel": and sharing. The definition is such that cell lines will exhibit important attributes. For example
"ent2": they will have a relatively homogenous cell type composition as they have experienced similar selective pressures due to their continuous co-propagation. In addition
column5: these populations can also be characterized by a passage number
column6: again owing to their common passaging history.?

"label": 3. Definitinal criteria are intended to be sufficiently clear to specify what are and what are not instances of 'cell lines' in the real world. A 'HeLa cell line' would be a subset of all HeLa cells in the world - specifically any subset that has been derived through a shared continuous lineage wherein the cells have always been passaged together and thereby evolved together through the selective pressures imposed by this common history. Accordingly
"ent1": 'HeLa cell line' would not be used to refer to the collection of all HeLa cells in a given lab
"rel": or all HeLa cells in the ATCC repository
"ent2": as cells in these collections will likely not all share a common culture history. Rather
column5: 'HeLa cell line' could refer to the collection of cells I am culturing at a given moment
column6: or that I apply in an experiment (as such collections typically meet the criteria of having a shared propagation history).  As noted above
column7: it is such collections that are typically referred to in scientific discourse and publications.

"ent1": the term 'line' has been alternately used by other terminologies and communities to refer to cultures that have been immortalized - ie has attained the capacity for indefinite propagation in vitro.  In this ontology
"rel": we refer to such cell lines as 'immortal cell lines'
"ent2": and use the term 'cell line' to indicate any culture that has been passaged."

"label": "The concept of a 'secondary cultured cell population' covers cell lines as well as cultured cell populations more immediately derived from a primary culture which have yet to achieve adequate genetic stability and compositional homogeneity to be considered a cell line. The extent of the collection of cells in a 'secondary cultured cell population' is restricted only in that all cell members must share a propagation history (ie be derived through a common lineage of passages from an initial culture).  Secondary cultured cell populations can be under active culture
"ent1": stored in a quiescent state for future use

"label": "1. The term 'line' is used when a culture has undergone an intentional experimental process to establish a more uniform and stable population of cells (see 'establishing cell line'). This will require one or more passages
"ent1": but may involve additional selection processes. Through such passaging and/or selection processes
"rel": the resulting 'line' attains some level of genetic stability and compositional homogeneity which is typically absent in primary cultures. Because of their relative homogeneity
"ent2": 'lines' are capable of being characterized and stably propagated over a period of time. A *new* cell line can be "established" not only through the passaging/selection of a primary culture
column5: but also through experimental modifications of existing lines (e.g. immortalization
column7: drug selection for a resistant subset
column8: etc.).  As defined here
column9: 'cell line' can refer to a population of cells in active culture
column10: applied experimentally
column11: or stored in a quescent state for future use.

"label": 2. The definitional criteria provided here for the 'cell line' class demarcates populations that represent what researchers actually use in the practice of science - e.g. as inputs to culturing
"rel": and sharing. The definition is such that cell lines will exhibit important attributes. For example
"ent2": they will have a relatively homogenous cell type composition as they have experienced similar selective pressures due to their continuous co-propagation. In addition
column5: these populations can also be characterized by a passage number
column6: again owing to their common passaging history.?

"label": 3. Definitinal criteria are intended to be sufficiently clear to specify what are and what are not instances of 'cell lines' in the real world. A 'HeLa cell line' would be a subset of all HeLa cells in the world - specifically any subset that has been derived through a shared continuous lineage wherein the cells have always been passaged together and thereby evolved together through the selective pressures imposed by this common history. Accordingly
"ent1": 'HeLa cell line' would not be used to refer to the collection of all HeLa cells in a given lab
"rel": or all HeLa cells in the ATCC repository
"ent2": as cells in these collections will likely not all share a common culture history. Rather
column5: 'HeLa cell line' could refer to the collection of cells I am culturing at a given moment
column6: or that I apply in an experiment (as such collections typically meet the criteria of having a shared propagation history).  As noted above
column7: it is such collections that are typically referred to in scientific discourse and publications.

"ent1": the term 'line' has been alternately used by other terminologies and communities to refer to cultures that have been immortalized - ie has attained the capacity for indefinite propagation in vitro.  In this ontology
"rel": we refer to such cell lines as 'immortal cell lines'
"ent2": and use the term 'cell line' to indicate any culture that has been passaged."

"label":
The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy

"label":
The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy

"label": Reagents are distinguished from devices/instruments that also serve as facilitators in scientific techniques by the fact that reagents are chemical or biological in nature and necessarily participate in or have parts that participate in some chemical interaction or reaction during their intended participation in some technique.  By contrast
"ent1": devices do not participate in a chemical reaction/interaction during the technique.

"label": Reagents are distinguished from study subjects/evaluants in that study subjects and evaluants are that about which conclusions are drawn and knowledge is sought in an investigation - while reagents
"rel": are not.  It should be noted
column5: that reagent and study subject/evaluant roles can be borne by instances of the same type of material entity - but a given instance can only realize one of these roles in the execution of a given  assay. For example
column6: taq polymerase can bear a reagent role or an evaluant role.  In a DNA sequencing assay aimed at generating sequence data about some plasmid
column7: the reagent role of the taq polymerase is realized. In an assay to evaluate the quality of the taq polymerase itself
column8: the evaluant/study subject role of the taq is realized
column9: but not the reagent role since the taq is the subject about which data is generated.

"label": In regard to the statement that reagents are 'distinct' from the specified outputs of a technique:  note that a reagent may be incorporated into a material output of a technique
"ent1": as long as the IDENTITY of this output is distinct from that of the bearer of the reagent role.  For example
"rel": dNTPs input into a PCR are reagents that become part of the material output of this technique
"ent2": but this output has a new identity (ie that of a 'nucleic acid molecule') that is distinct from the identity of the dNTPs that comprise it.  Similarly
column5: a biotin molecule input into a cell labeling technique are reagents that become part of the specified output
column6: but the identity of the output is that of some modified cell specimen which shares identity with the input unmodified cell specimen
column7: and not with the biotin label. Thus
column8: we see that an important criteria of 'reagent-ness' is that it is a facilitator
column9: and not the primary focus of an investigation or material processing technique (ie not the specified subject/evaluant about which knowledge is sought
column10: or the specified output material of the technique)."

column13: "2013-6-5 MHB: Clarifications regarding the distinction between reagetns and devices were made at the May 2013 Philly Workshop. Reagents are distinguished from devices that also participate in scientific techniques by the fact that reagents are chemical or biological in nature and necessarily participate in some chemical interaction or reaction during the realization of their experimental role. By contrast
column14: devices do not participate in such chemical reactions/interactions.  Note that there are cases where devices use reagent components during their operation
column15: where the reagent-device distinction is less clear.  For examples

"label": "The concept of a 'secondary cultured cell population' covers cell lines as well as cultured cell populations more immediately derived from a primary culture which have yet to achieve adequate genetic stability and compositional homogeneity to be considered a cell line. The extent of the collection of cells in a 'secondary cultured cell population' is restricted only in that all cell members must share a propagation history (ie be derived through a common lineage of passages from an initial culture).  Secondary cultured cell populations can be under active culture
"ent1": stored in a quiescent state for future use
column6: "The term 'secondary cell culture' is generally used in biological texts/protocols to refer to any culture of cells following an initial passage.  We include it here because there are often a number of passages between a primary culture and the establishment of a stable
column7: homogenous cell line.  Such cultures are considered to be 'secondary cultures' but not 'cell lines' during this intermediate passaging/selection period between their derivation from a 'primary cell culture' and derivation into a 'cell line'
column8: which is a more specific type of secondary culture."

"label": "1. The term 'line' is used when a culture has undergone an intentional experimental process to establish a more uniform and stable population of cells (see 'establishing cell line'). This will require one or more passages
"ent1": but may involve additional selection processes. Through such passaging and/or selection processes
"rel": the resulting 'line' attains some level of genetic stability and compositional homogeneity which is typically absent in primary cultures. Because of their relative homogeneity
"ent2": 'lines' are capable of being characterized and stably propagated over a period of time. A *new* cell line can be "established" not only through the passaging/selection of a primary culture
column5: but also through experimental modifications of existing lines (e.g. immortalization
column7: drug selection for a resistant subset
column8: etc.).  As defined here
column9: 'cell line' can refer to a population of cells in active culture
column10: applied experimentally
column11: or stored in a quescent state for future use.

"label": 2. The definitional criteria provided here for the 'cell line' class demarcates populations that represent what researchers actually use in the practice of science - e.g. as inputs to culturing
"rel": and sharing. The definition is such that cell lines will exhibit important attributes. For example
"ent2": they will have a relatively homogenous cell type composition as they have experienced similar selective pressures due to their continuous co-propagation. In addition
column5: these populations can also be characterized by a passage number
column6: again owing to their common passaging history.?

"label": 3. Definitinal criteria are intended to be sufficiently clear to specify what are and what are not instances of 'cell lines' in the real world. A 'HeLa cell line' would be a subset of all HeLa cells in the world - specifically any subset that has been derived through a shared continuous lineage wherein the cells have always been passaged together and thereby evolved together through the selective pressures imposed by this common history. Accordingly
"ent1": 'HeLa cell line' would not be used to refer to the collection of all HeLa cells in a given lab
"rel": or all HeLa cells in the ATCC repository
"ent2": as cells in these collections will likely not all share a common culture history. Rather
column5: 'HeLa cell line' could refer to the collection of cells I am culturing at a given moment
column6: or that I apply in an experiment (as such collections typically meet the criteria of having a shared propagation history).  As noted above
column7: it is such collections that are typically referred to in scientific discourse and publications.

"ent1": the term 'line' has been alternately used by other terminologies and communities to refer to cultures that have been immortalized - ie has attained the capacity for indefinite propagation in vitro.  In this ontology
"rel": we refer to such cell lines as 'immortal cell lines'
"ent2": and use the term 'cell line' to indicate any culture that has been passaged."
column7: "2013-08-09 MHB: Replaced with cell line class from CLO
column8: follwoing outcome of Spring 2013 CLO alignment work.  Subclass axioms were: 'has grain' some 'cell line cell' and 'has grain' only 'cell line cell'

"label": 2013-6-5 MHB: There is considerable ambiguity and inconsistent usage surrounding the term 'cell line' across biomedical communities. For exmaple
"ent1": it can refer to the maximal collection of all cells in a cultured lineage (e.g. the colelction of all HeLa cells that exist)
"rel": or to discrete portions of this maximal collection that are stored
column5: and applied experimentally (e.g. the dish of HeLa cells I am using in my experiment). A working group of representatives from OBI
column7: and CL was assembled in spring of 2013 to harmonize modeling and terminology surrounding experimentally cultured cells across Open Biomedical Ontologies
column8: following OBO Foundry principles of orthogonality and re-use. A consensus was reached to apply the term 'cell line' to refer not to a maximal collection of cells of a given type
column9: but to discrete populations of cultured cells that share a common propagation history which has conferred a certain a genetic stability and compositional homogeneity to the population.  This meaning reflects its most common usage in domain discourse
column10: and will best support data annotation requirements. This view means that a 'HeLa cell line' would be a subset of all HeLa cells in the world - specifically any subset that has been derived through a shared continuous lineage wherein the cells have always been passaged together and thereby evolved together through the selective pressures imposed by this specific history. Accordingly
column11: 'HeLa cell line' would not be used to refer to collections such as all HeLa cells in a given lab
column12: or all HeLa cells in the ATCC repository
column13: as all cells in these collections do not necessarily share a common culture history. Rather
column14: it could be used to refer to the collection of cells I am culturing at a given moment
column15: or that I apply in an experiment (as such collections typically meet the criteria of having a shared propagation history).

"label": This approach seems to accomplish several desirable goals:
1) It allows us to define the term 'cell line' for the community in a precise way that also reflects how the term is most commonly used in the literature and scientific discourse.
(2) It gives a definition that provides clear criteria to help specify what are and what are not instances of 'cell lines' in the real world
(3) The criteria it provides demarcate populations that represent what researchers actually use in the practice of science - ie are the inputs to culturing
"rel": and sharing. The cells in such populations will be a relatively uniform population as they have experienced similar selective pressures due to their continuous co-propagation. And this population will also have a single passage number
"ent2": again owing to their common passaging history.

"label": (4) The definition seems to be true to the meaning of the word 'line' - which is suggests a specific lineage of derivation."

"rel": the resulting 'line' attains some level of genetic stability and compositional homogeneity which is typically absent in primary cultures. Because of their relative homogeneity
"ent2": 'lines' are capable of being characterized and stably propagated over a period of time. A *new* cell line can be "established" not only through the passaging/selection of a primary culture
column5: but also through experimental modifications of existing lines (e.g. immortalization
column7: drug selection for a resistant subset
column8: etc.).  As defined here
column9: 'cell line' can refer to a population of cells in active culture
column10: applied experimentally
column11: or stored in a quescent state for future use.

"label": 2. The definitional criteria provided here for the 'cell line' class demarcates populations that represent what researchers actually use in the practice of science - e.g. as inputs to culturing
"rel": and sharing. The definition is such that cell lines will exhibit important attributes. For example
"ent2": they will have a relatively homogenous cell type composition as they have experienced similar selective pressures due to their continuous co-propagation. In addition
column5: these populations can also be characterized by a passage number
column6: again owing to their common passaging history.?

"label": 3. Definitinal criteria are intended to be sufficiently clear to specify what are and what are not instances of 'cell lines' in the real world. A 'HeLa cell line' would be a subset of all HeLa cells in the world - specifically any subset that has been derived through a shared continuous lineage wherein the cells have always been passaged together and thereby evolved together through the selective pressures imposed by this common history. Accordingly
"ent1": 'HeLa cell line' would not be used to refer to the collection of all HeLa cells in a given lab
"rel": or all HeLa cells in the ATCC repository
"ent2": as cells in these collections will likely not all share a common culture history. Rather
column5: 'HeLa cell line' could refer to the collection of cells I am culturing at a given moment
column6: or that I apply in an experiment (as such collections typically meet the criteria of having a shared propagation history).  As noted above
column7: it is such collections that are typically referred to in scientific discourse and publications.

"ent1": the term 'line' has been alternately used by other terminologies and communities to refer to cultures that have been immortalized - ie has attained the capacity for indefinite propagation in vitro.  In this ontology
"rel": we refer to such cell lines as 'immortal cell lines'
"ent2": and use the term 'cell line' to indicate any culture that has been passaged."

"label": Reagents are distinguished from instruments or devices that also participate in scientific techniques by the fact that reagents are chemical or biological in nature and necessarily participate in or have parts that participate in some chemical interaction or reaction during their intended participation in some technique.  By contrast
"ent1": instruments do not participate in a chemical reaction/interaction during the technique.

"label": Reagents are distinguished from study subjects/evaluants in that study subjects and evaluants are that about which conclusions are drawn and knowledge is sought in an investigation - while reagents
"rel": are not.  It should be noted
column5: that reagent and study subject/evaluant roles can be borne by instances of the same type of material entity - but a given instance will realize only one of these roles in the execution of a given assay or technique. For example
column6: taq polymerase can bear a reagent role or an evaluant role.  In a DNA sequencing assay aimed at generating sequence data about some plasmid
column7: the reagent role of the taq polymerase is realized. In an assay to evaluate the quality of the taq polymerase itself
column8: the evaluant/study subject role of the taq is realized
column9: but not the reagent role since the taq is the subject about which data is generated.

"label": In regard to the statement that reagents are 'distinct' from the specified outputs of a technique
"ent1": note that a reagent may be incorporated into a material output of a technique
"rel": as long as the IDENTITY of this output is distinct from that of the bearer of the reagent role.  For example
"ent2": dNTPs input into a PCR are reagents that become part of the material output of this technique
column5: but this output has a new identity (ie that of a 'nucleic acid molecule') that is distinct from the identity of the dNTPs that comprise it.  Similarly
column6: a biotin molecule input into a cell labeling technique are reagents that become part of the specified output
column7: but the identity of the output is that of some modified cell specimen which shares identity with the input unmodified cell specimen
column8: and not with the biotin label. Thus
column9: we see that an important criteria of 'reagent-ness' is that it is a facilitator
column10: and not the primary focus of an investigation or material processing technique (ie not the specified subject/evaluant about which knowledge is sought
column11: or the specified output material of the technique)."

column7: Stefan Schulz
column8: Marijke Keet
column9: Melanie Courtot
column10: and Alan Ruttenberg. With inspiration from the paper Granularity

"label": "The concept of a 'secondary cultured cell population' covers cell lines as well as cultured cell populations more immediately derived from a primary culture which have yet to achieve adequate genetic stability and compositional homogeneity to be considered a cell line. The extent of the collection of cells in a 'secondary cultured cell population' is restricted only in that all cell members must share a propagation history (ie be derived through a common lineage of passages from an initial culture).  Secondary cultured cell populations can be under active culture

"label": May 28 2013. Updated definition taken from ReO based on discussions initiated in Philly 2011 workshop.  Former defnition described a narrower view of reagents in chemistry that restricts bearers of the role to be chemical entities ("a role played by a molecular entity used to produce a chemical reaction to detect
"rel": or produce other substances").  Updated definition allows for broader view of reagents in the domain of biomedical research to include larger materials that have parts that participate chemically in a molecular reaction or interaction.

"ent1": soil is referred to as regolith
"rel": or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically
"ent2": the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

"label":
The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy

column8: preparation or treatment of "food" but does not include cosmetics or tobacco or substances used only as drugs." (Nutrition Division/Meeting Programming and Documentation Service
column9: FAO
column10: 2013 (MI198) adopted from Codex Alimentarius Commission

Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. "label": Reagents are distinguished from instruments or devices that also participate in scientific techniques by the fact that reagents are chemical or biological in nature and necessarily participate in or have parts that participate in some chemical interaction or reaction during their intended participation in some technique.  By contrast
"ent1": instruments do not participate in a chemical reaction/interaction during the technique.

"label": Reagents are distinguished from study subjects/evaluants in that study subjects and evaluants are that about which conclusions are drawn and knowledge is sought in an investigation - while reagents
"rel": are not.  It should be noted
column5: that reagent and study subject/evaluant roles can be borne by instances of the same type of material entity - but a given instance will realize only one of these roles in the execution of a given assay or technique. For example
column6: taq polymerase can bear a reagent role or an evaluant role.  In a DNA sequencing assay aimed at generating sequence data about some plasmid
column7: the reagent role of the taq polymerase is realized. In an assay to evaluate the quality of the taq polymerase itself
column8: the evaluant/study subject role of the taq is realized
column9: but not the reagent role since the taq is the subject about which data is generated.

"label": In regard to the statement that reagents are 'distinct' from the specified outputs of a technique
"ent1": note that a reagent may be incorporated into a material output of a technique
"rel": as long as the IDENTITY of this output is distinct from that of the bearer of the reagent role.  For example
"ent2": dNTPs input into a PCR are reagents that become part of the material output of this technique
column5: but this output has a new identity (ie that of a 'nucleic acid molecule') that is distinct from the identity of the dNTPs that comprise it.  Similarly
column6: a biotin molecule input into a cell labeling technique are reagents that become part of the specified output
column7: but the identity of the output is that of some modified cell specimen which shares identity with the input unmodified cell specimen
column8: and not with the biotin label. Thus
column9: we see that an important criteria of 'reagent-ness' is that it is a facilitator
column10: and not the primary focus of an investigation or material processing technique (ie not the specified subject/evaluant about which knowledge is sought
column11: or the specified output material of the technique)."

"rel": as long as the IDENTITY of this output is distinct from that of the bearer of the reagent role.  For example
"ent2": dNTPs input into a PCR are reagents that become part of the material output of this technique
column5: but this output has a new identity (ie that of a 'nucleic acid molecule') that is distinct from the identity of the dNTPs that comprise it.  Similarly
column6: a biotin molecule input into a cell labeling technique are reagents that become part of the specified output
column7: but the identity of the output is that of some modified cell specimen which shares identity with the input unmodified cell specimen
column8: and not with the biotin label. Thus
column9: we see that an important criteria of 'reagent-ness' is that it is a facilitator
column10: and not the primary focus of an investigation or material processing technique (ie not the specified subject/evaluant about which knowledge is sought
column11: or the specified output material of the technique)."

"label": Reagents are distinguished from instruments or devices that also participate in scientific techniques by the fact that reagents are chemical or biological in nature and necessarily participate in or have parts that participate in some chemical interaction or reaction during their intended participation in some technique.  By contrast
"ent1": instruments do not participate in a chemical reaction/interaction during the technique.

"label": Reagents are distinguished from study subjects/evaluants in that study subjects and evaluants are that about which conclusions are drawn and knowledge is sought in an investigation - while reagents
"rel": are not.  It should be noted
column5: that reagent and study subject/evaluant roles can be borne by instances of the same type of material entity - but a given instance will realize only one of these roles in the execution of a given assay or technique. For example
column6: taq polymerase can bear a reagent role or an evaluant role.  In a DNA sequencing assay aimed at generating sequence data about some plasmid
column7: the reagent role of the taq polymerase is realized. In an assay to evaluate the quality of the taq polymerase itself
column8: the evaluant/study subject role of the taq is realized
column9: but not the reagent role since the taq is the subject about which data is generated.

"ent1": soil is referred to as regolith
"rel": or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically
"ent2": the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

"label":
The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy

"ent2": dNTPs input into a PCR are reagents that become part of the material output of this technique
column5: but this output has a new identity (ie that of a 'nucleic acid molecule') that is distinct from the identity of the dNTPs that comprise it.  Similarly
column6: a biotin molecule input into a cell labeling technique are reagents that become part of the specified output
column7: but the identity of the output is that of some modified cell specimen which shares identity with the input unmodified cell specimen
column8: and not with the biotin label. Thus
column9: we see that an important criteria of 'reagent-ness' is that it is a facilitator
column10: and not the primary focus of an investigation or material processing technique (ie not the specified subject/evaluant about which knowledge is sought
column11: or the specified output material of the technique)."

"ent1": soil is referred to as regolith
"rel": or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically
"ent2": the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

"label":
The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy

Reagents are distinguished from instruments or devices that also participate in scientific techniques by the fact that reagents are chemical or biological in nature and necessarily participate in or have parts that participate in some chemical interaction or reaction during their intended participation in some technique.  By contrast
"ent1": instruments do not participate in a chemical reaction/interaction during the technique.

"label": Reagents are distinguished from study subjects/evaluants in that study subjects and evaluants are that about which conclusions are drawn and knowledge is sought in an investigation - while reagents
"rel": are not.  It should be noted
column5: that reagent and study subject/evaluant roles can be borne by instances of the same type of material entity - but a given instance will realize only one of these roles in the execution of a given assay or technique. For example
column6: taq polymerase can bear a reagent role or an evaluant role.  In a DNA sequencing assay aimed at generating sequence data about some plasmid
column7: the reagent role of the taq polymerase is realized. In an assay to evaluate the quality of the taq polymerase itself
column8: the evaluant/study subject role of the taq is realized
column9: but not the reagent role since the taq is the subject about which data is generated.

"rel": as long as the IDENTITY of this output is distinct from that of the bearer of the reagent role.  For example

column6: a biotin molecule input into a cell labeling technique are reagents that become part of the specified output
column7: but the identity of the output is that of some modified cell specimen which shares identity with the input unmodified cell specimen
column8: and not with the biotin label. Thus
column9: we see that an important criteria of 'reagent-ness' is that it is a facilitator
column10: and not the primary focus of an investigation or material processing technique (ie not the specified subject/evaluant about which knowledge is sought
column11: or the specified output material of the technique)."

"label": "From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ [A mineral] is different from a rock
"ent1": which can be an aggregate of minerals or non-minerals and does not have a specific chemical composition. The exact definition of a mineral is under debate
"rel": especially with respect to the requirement a valid species be abiogenic
"ent2": and to a lesser extent with regards to it having an ordered atomic structure."
column7: "http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00001995"

"ent1": soil is referred to as regolith

"label":
The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy

"label": "The concept of a 'secondary cultured cell population' covers cell lines as well as cultured cell populations more immediately derived from a primary culture which have yet to achieve adequate genetic stability and compositional homogeneity to be considered a cell line. The extent of the collection of cells in a 'secondary cultured cell population' is restricted only in that all cell members must share a propagation history (ie be derived through a common lineage of passages from an initial culture).  Secondary cultured cell populations can be under active culture
"ent1": stored in a quiescent state for future use

"label": "1. The term 'line' is used when a culture has undergone an intentional experimental process to establish a more uniform and stable population of cells (see 'establishing cell line'). This will require one or more passages
"ent1": but may involve additional selection processes. Through such passaging and/or selection processes
"rel": the resulting 'line' attains some level of genetic stability and compositional homogeneity which is typically absent in primary cultures. Because of their relative homogeneity
"ent2": 'lines' are capable of being characterized and stably propagated over a period of time. A *new* cell line can be "established" not only through the passaging/selection of a primary culture
column5: but also through experimental modifications of existing lines (e.g. immortalization
column7: drug selection for a resistant subset
column8: etc.).  As defined here
column9: 'cell line' can refer to a population of cells in active culture
column10: applied experimentally
column11: or stored in a quescent state for future use.

"label": 2. The definitional criteria provided here for the 'cell line' class demarcates populations that represent what researchers actually use in the practice of science - e.g. as inputs to culturing
"rel": and sharing. The definition is such that cell lines will exhibit important attributes. For example
"ent2": they will have a relatively homogenous cell type composition as they have experienced similar selective pressures due to their continuous co-propagation. In addition
column5: these populations can also be characterized by a passage number
column6: again owing to their common passaging history.?

"label": 3. Definitinal criteria are intended to be sufficiently clear to specify what are and what are not instances of 'cell lines' in the real world. A 'HeLa cell line' would be a subset of all HeLa cells in the world - specifically any subset that has been derived through a shared continuous lineage wherein the cells have always been passaged together and thereby evolved together through the selective pressures imposed by this common history. Accordingly
"ent1": 'HeLa cell line' would not be used to refer to the collection of all HeLa cells in a given lab
"rel": or all HeLa cells in the ATCC repository
"ent2": as cells in these collections will likely not all share a common culture history. Rather
column5: 'HeLa cell line' could refer to the collection of cells I am culturing at a given moment
column6: or that I apply in an experiment (as such collections typically meet the criteria of having a shared propagation history).  As noted above
column7: it is such collections that are typically referred to in scientific discourse and publications.

"ent1": the term 'line' has been alternately used by other terminologies and communities to refer to cultures that have been immortalized - ie has attained the capacity for indefinite propagation in vitro.  In this ontology
"rel": we refer to such cell lines as 'immortal cell lines'
"ent2": and use the term 'cell line' to indicate any culture that has been passaged."

"ent1": soil is referred to as regolith
"rel": or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically
"ent2": the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

"label":
The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy

"label": ""Soil Erosion is a common term that is often confused with soil degradation as a whole
"ent1": but in fact refers only to absolute soil losses in terms of topsoil and nutrients. This  is indeed the most visible effect of soil degradation
"rel": but does not cover all of its aspects. Soil erosion is a natural process in mountainous areas
"ent2": but is often made much worse by poor management practices." http://www.fao.org/soils-portal/soil-degradation-restoration/en/"

"label": Reagents are distinguished from instruments or devices that also participate in scientific techniques by the fact that reagents are chemical or biological in nature and necessarily participate in or have parts that participate in some chemical interaction or reaction during their intended participation in some technique.  By contrast
"ent1": instruments do not participate in a chemical reaction/interaction during the technique.

"label": Reagents are distinguished from study subjects/evaluants in that study subjects and evaluants are that about which conclusions are drawn and knowledge is sought in an investigation - while reagents
"rel": are not.  It should be noted
column5: that reagent and study subject/evaluant roles can be borne by instances of the same type of material entity - but a given instance will realize only one of these roles in the execution of a given assay or technique. For example
column6: taq polymerase can bear a reagent role or an evaluant role.  In a DNA sequencing assay aimed at generating sequence data about some plasmid
column7: the reagent role of the taq polymerase is realized. In an assay to evaluate the quality of the taq polymerase itself
column8: the evaluant/study subject role of the taq is realized
column9: but not the reagent role since the taq is the subject about which data is generated.

"label": In regard to the statement that reagents are 'distinct' from the specified outputs of a technique
"ent1": note that a reagent may be incorporated into a material output of a technique
"rel": as long as the IDENTITY of this output is distinct from that of the bearer of the reagent role.  For example
"ent2": dNTPs input into a PCR are reagents that become part of the material output of this technique
column5: but this output has a new identity (ie that of a 'nucleic acid molecule') that is distinct from the identity of the dNTPs that comprise it.  Similarly
column6: a biotin molecule input into a cell labeling technique are reagents that become part of the specified output
column7: but the identity of the output is that of some modified cell specimen which shares identity with the input unmodified cell specimen
column8: and not with the biotin label. Thus
column9: we see that an important criteria of 'reagent-ness' is that it is a facilitator
column10: and not the primary focus of an investigation or material processing technique (ie not the specified subject/evaluant about which knowledge is sought
column11: or the specified output material of the technique)."

"label": "The concept of a 'secondary cultured cell population' covers cell lines as well as cultured cell populations more immediately derived from a primary culture which have yet to achieve adequate genetic stability and compositional homogeneity to be considered a cell line. The extent of the collection of cells in a 'secondary cultured cell population' is restricted only in that all cell members must share a propagation history (ie be derived through a common lineage of passages from an initial culture).  Secondary cultured cell populations can be under active culture
"ent1": stored in a quiescent state for future use
column6: "The concept of a 'secondary cultured cell population' covers cell lines as well as cultured cell populations more immediately derived from a primary culture which have yet to achieve adequate genetic stability and compositional homogeneity to be considered a cell line. The extent of the collection of cells in a 'secondary cultured cell population' is restricted only in that all cell members must share a propagation history (ie be derived through a common lineage of passages from an initial culture).  Secondary cultured cell populations can be under active culture
column7: stored in a quiescent state for future use
column8: or applied experimentally."

"label": "1. The term 'line' is used when a culture has undergone an intentional experimental process to establish a more uniform and stable population of cells (see 'establishing cell line'). This will require one or more passages
"ent1": but may involve additional selection processes. Through such passaging and/or selection processes
"rel": the resulting 'line' attains some level of genetic stability and compositional homogeneity which is typically absent in primary cultures. Because of their relative homogeneity
"ent2": 'lines' are capable of being characterized and stably propagated over a period of time. A *new* cell line can be "established" not only through the passaging/selection of a primary culture
column5: but also through experimental modifications of existing lines (e.g. immortalization
column7: drug selection for a resistant subset
column8: etc.).  As defined here
column9: 'cell line' can refer to a population of cells in active culture
column10: applied experimentally
column11: or stored in a quescent state for future use.

"label": 2. The definitional criteria provided here for the 'cell line' class demarcates populations that represent what researchers actually use in the practice of science - e.g. as inputs to culturing
"rel": and sharing. The definition is such that cell lines will exhibit important attributes. For example
"ent2": they will have a relatively homogenous cell type composition as they have experienced similar selective pressures due to their continuous co-propagation. In addition
column5: these populations can also be characterized by a passage number
column6: again owing to their common passaging history.?

"label": 3. Definitinal criteria are intended to be sufficiently clear to specify what are and what are not instances of 'cell lines' in the real world. A 'HeLa cell line' would be a subset of all HeLa cells in the world - specifically any subset that has been derived through a shared continuous lineage wherein the cells have always been passaged together and thereby evolved together through the selective pressures imposed by this common history. Accordingly
"ent1": 'HeLa cell line' would not be used to refer to the collection of all HeLa cells in a given lab
"rel": or all HeLa cells in the ATCC repository
"ent2": as cells in these collections will likely not all share a common culture history. Rather
column5: 'HeLa cell line' could refer to the collection of cells I am culturing at a given moment
column6: or that I apply in an experiment (as such collections typically meet the criteria of having a shared propagation history).  As noted above
column7: it is such collections that are typically referred to in scientific discourse and publications.

"ent1": the term 'line' has been alternately used by other terminologies and communities to refer to cultures that have been immortalized - ie has attained the capacity for indefinite propagation in vitro.  In this ontology
"rel": we refer to such cell lines as 'immortal cell lines'
"ent2": and use the term 'cell line' to indicate any culture that has been passaged."

"label": Reagents are distinguished from instruments or devices that also participate in scientific techniques by the fact that reagents are chemical or biological in nature and necessarily participate in or have parts that participate in some chemical interaction or reaction during their intended participation in some technique.  By contrast
"ent1": instruments do not participate in a chemical reaction/interaction during the technique.

"label": Reagents are distinguished from study subjects/evaluants in that study subjects and evaluants are that about which conclusions are drawn and knowledge is sought in an investigation - while reagents
"rel": are not.  It should be noted
column5: that reagent and study subject/evaluant roles can be borne by instances of the same type of material entity - but a given instance will realize only one of these roles in the execution of a given assay or technique. For example
column6: taq polymerase can bear a reagent role or an evaluant role.  In a DNA sequencing assay aimed at generating sequence data about some plasmid
column7: the reagent role of the taq polymerase is realized. In an assay to evaluate the quality of the taq polymerase itself
column8: the evaluant/study subject role of the taq is realized
column9: but not the reagent role since the taq is the subject about which data is generated.

"label": In regard to the statement that reagents are 'distinct' from the specified outputs of a technique
"ent1": note that a reagent may be incorporated into a material output of a technique
"rel": as long as the IDENTITY of this output is distinct from that of the bearer of the reagent role.  For example
"ent2": dNTPs input into a PCR are reagents that become part of the material output of this technique
column5: but this output has a new identity (ie that of a 'nucleic acid molecule') that is distinct from the identity of the dNTPs that comprise it.  Similarly
column6: a biotin molecule input into a cell labeling technique are reagents that become part of the specified output
column7: but the identity of the output is that of some modified cell specimen which shares identity with the input unmodified cell specimen
column8: and not with the biotin label. Thus
column9: we see that an important criteria of 'reagent-ness' is that it is a facilitator
column10: and not the primary focus of an investigation or material processing technique (ie not the specified subject/evaluant about which knowledge is sought
column11: or the specified output material of the technique)."

"label": "The concept of a 'secondary cultured cell population' covers cell lines as well as cultured cell populations more immediately derived from a primary culture which have yet to achieve adequate genetic stability and compositional homogeneity to be considered a cell line. The extent of the collection of cells in a 'secondary cultured cell population' is restricted only in that all cell members must share a propagation history (ie be derived through a common lineage of passages from an initial culture).  Secondary cultured cell populations can be under active culture
"ent1": stored in a quiescent state for future use

"label": "1. The term 'line' is used when a culture has undergone an intentional experimental process to establish a more uniform and stable population of cells (see 'establishing cell line'). This will require one or more passages
"ent1": but may involve additional selection processes. Through such passaging and/or selection processes
"rel": the resulting 'line' attains some level of genetic stability and compositional homogeneity which is typically absent in primary cultures. Because of their relative homogeneity
"ent2": 'lines' are capable of being characterized and stably propagated over a period of time. A *new* cell line can be "established" not only through the passaging/selection of a primary culture
column5: but also through experimental modifications of existing lines (e.g. immortalization
column7: drug selection for a resistant subset
column8: etc.).  As defined here
column9: 'cell line' can refer to a population of cells in active culture
column10: applied experimentally
column11: or stored in a quescent state for future use.

"label": 2. The definitional criteria provided here for the 'cell line' class demarcates populations that represent what researchers actually use in the practice of science - e.g. as inputs to culturing
"rel": and sharing. The definition is such that cell lines will exhibit important attributes. For example
"ent2": they will have a relatively homogenous cell type composition as they have experienced similar selective pressures due to their continuous co-propagation. In addition
column5: these populations can also be characterized by a passage number
column6: again owing to their common passaging history.?

"label": 3. Definitinal criteria are intended to be sufficiently clear to specify what are and what are not instances of 'cell lines' in the real world. A 'HeLa cell line' would be a subset of all HeLa cells in the world - specifically any subset that has been derived through a shared continuous lineage wherein the cells have always been passaged together and thereby evolved together through the selective pressures imposed by this common history. Accordingly
"ent1": 'HeLa cell line' would not be used to refer to the collection of all HeLa cells in a given lab
"rel": or all HeLa cells in the ATCC repository
"ent2": as cells in these collections will likely not all share a common culture history. Rather
column5: 'HeLa cell line' could refer to the collection of cells I am culturing at a given moment
column6: or that I apply in an experiment (as such collections typically meet the criteria of having a shared propagation history).  As noted above
column7: it is such collections that are typically referred to in scientific discourse and publications.

"ent1": the term 'line' has been alternately used by other terminologies and communities to refer to cultures that have been immortalized - ie has attained the capacity for indefinite propagation in vitro.  In this ontology
"rel": we refer to such cell lines as 'immortal cell lines'
"ent2": and use the term 'cell line' to indicate any culture that has been passaged."
column7: "obsolete_cell line"

"rel": especially with respect to the requirement a valid species be abiogenic
"ent2": and to a lesser extent with regards to it having an ordered atomic structure."
column7: "http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00001995"

"label": "It's possible that this will become an inferred class in the future. The United Nations' International Standard Industrial Classification should be referred to when expanding this branch. ISIC can also be used to identify processes. See http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=27&Lg=1."

"ent1": soil is referred to as regolith
"rel": or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically
"ent2": the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

"label":
The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy

The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy

"ent1": soil is referred to as regolith
"rel": or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically
"ent2": the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy

"ent1": soil is referred to as regolith
"rel": or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically
"ent2": the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

"label": ""Soil Erosion is a common term that is often confused with soil degradation as a whole
"ent1": but in fact refers only to absolute soil losses in terms of topsoil and nutrients. This  is indeed the most visible effect of soil degradation
"rel": but does not cover all of its aspects. Soil erosion is a natural process in mountainous areas
"ent2": but is often made much worse by poor management practices." http://www.fao.org/soils-portal/soil-degradation-restoration/en/"

"label": Reagents are distinguished from instruments or devices that also participate in scientific techniques by the fact that reagents are chemical or biological in nature and necessarily participate in or have parts that participate in some chemical interaction or reaction during their intended participation in some technique.  By contrast
"ent1": instruments do not participate in a chemical reaction/interaction during the technique.

"label": Reagents are distinguished from study subjects/evaluants in that study subjects and evaluants are that about which conclusions are drawn and knowledge is sought in an investigation - while reagents
"rel": are not.  It should be noted
column5: that reagent and study subject/evaluant roles can be borne by instances of the same type of material entity - but a given instance will realize only one of these roles in the execution of a given assay or technique. For example
column6: taq polymerase can bear a reagent role or an evaluant role.  In a DNA sequencing assay aimed at generating sequence data about some plasmid
column7: the reagent role of the taq polymerase is realized. In an assay to evaluate the quality of the taq polymerase itself
column8: the evaluant/study subject role of the taq is realized
column9: but not the reagent role since the taq is the subject about which data is generated.

"label": In regard to the statement that reagents are 'distinct' from the specified outputs of a technique
"ent1": note that a reagent may be incorporated into a material output of a technique
"rel": as long as the IDENTITY of this output is distinct from that of the bearer of the reagent role.  For example
"ent2": dNTPs input into a PCR are reagents that become part of the material output of this technique
column5: but this output has a new identity (ie that of a 'nucleic acid molecule') that is distinct from the identity of the dNTPs that comprise it.  Similarly
column6: a biotin molecule input into a cell labeling technique are reagents that become part of the specified output
column7: but the identity of the output is that of some modified cell specimen which shares identity with the input unmodified cell specimen
column8: and not with the biotin label. Thus
column9: we see that an important criteria of 'reagent-ness' is that it is a facilitator
column10: and not the primary focus of an investigation or material processing technique (ie not the specified subject/evaluant about which knowledge is sought
column11: or the specified output material of the technique)."

"label": Reagents are distinguished from study subjects/evaluants in that study subjects and evaluants are that about which conclusions are drawn and knowledge is sought in an investigation - while reagents
"rel": are not.  It should be noted
column5: that reagent and study subject/evaluant roles can be borne by instances of the same type of material entity - but a given instance can only realize one of these roles in the execution of a given  assay. For example
column6: taq polymerase can bear a reagent role or an evaluant role.  In a DNA sequencing assay aimed at generating sequence data about some plasmid
column7: the reagent role of the taq polymerase is realized. In an assay to evaluate the quality of the taq polymerase itself
column8: the evaluant/study subject role of the taq is realized
column9: but not the reagent role since the taq is the subject about which data is generated.

"label": In regard to the statement that reagents are 'distinct' from the specified outputs of a technique:  note that a reagent may be incorporated into a material output of a technique
"ent1": as long as the IDENTITY of this output is distinct from that of the bearer of the reagent role.  For example
"rel": dNTPs input into a PCR are reagents that become part of the material output of this technique
"ent2": but this output has a new identity (ie that of a 'nucleic acid molecule') that is distinct from the identity of the dNTPs that comprise it.  Similarly
column5: a biotin molecule input into a cell labeling technique are reagents that become part of the specified output
column6: but the identity of the output is that of some modified cell specimen which shares identity with the input unmodified cell specimen
column7: and not with the biotin label. Thus
column8: we see that an important criteria of 'reagent-ness' is that it is a facilitator
column9: and not the primary focus of an investigation or material processing technique (ie not the specified subject/evaluant about which knowledge is sought

"label": "The concept of a 'secondary cultured cell population' covers cell lines as well as cultured cell populations more immediately derived from a primary culture which have yet to achieve adequate genetic stability and compositional homogeneity to be considered a cell line. Secondary cultured cell populations can be under active culture

"label": "1. The term 'line' is used when a culture has undergone an intentional experimental process to establish a more uniform and stable population of cells (see 'establishing cell line'). This will require one or more passages
"ent1": but may involve additional selection processes. Through such passaging and/or selection processes
"rel": the resulting 'line' attains some level of genetic stability and compositional homogeneity which is typically absent in primary cultures. Because of their relative homogeneity
"ent2": 'lines' are capable of being characterized and stably propagated over a period of time. A *new* cell line can be "established" not only through the passaging/selection of a primary culture
column5: but also through experimental modifications of existing lines (e.g. immortalization
column7: drug selection for a resistant subset
column8: etc.).  As defined here
column9: 'cell line' can refer to a population of cells in active culture
column10: applied experimentally
column11: or stored in a quescent state for future use.

"label": 2. The definitional criteria provided here for the 'cell line' class demarcates populations that represent what researchers actually use in the practice of science - e.g. as inputs to culturing
"rel": and sharing. The definition is such that cell lines will exhibit important attributes. For example
"ent2": they will have a relatively homogenous cell type composition as they have experienced similar selective pressures due to their continuous co-propagation. In addition
column5: these populations can also be characterized by a passage number
column6: again owing to their common passaging history.?

"label": 3. Definitinal criteria are intended to be sufficiently clear to specify what are and what are not instances of 'cell lines' in the real world. A 'HeLa cell line' would be a subset of all HeLa cells in the world - specifically any subset that has been derived through a shared continuous lineage wherein the cells have always been passaged together and thereby evolved together through the selective pressures imposed by this common history. Accordingly
"ent1": 'HeLa cell line' would not be used to refer to the collection of all HeLa cells in a given lab
"rel": or all HeLa cells in the ATCC repository
"ent2": as cells in these collections will likely not all share a common culture history. Rather
column5: 'HeLa cell line' could refer to the collection of cells I am culturing at a given moment
column6: or that I apply in an experiment (as such collections typically meet the criteria of having a shared propagation history).  As noted above
column7: it is such collections that are typically referred to in scientific discourse and publications.

"ent1": the term 'line' has been alternately used by other terminologies and communities to refer to cultures that have been immortalized - ie has attained the capacity for indefinite propagation in vitro.  In this ontology
"rel": we refer to such cell lines as 'immortal cell lines'
"ent2": and use the term 'cell line' to indicate any culture that has been passaged."
column7: "http://www.geneontology.org/formats/oboInOwl#ObsoleteClass"

"label":
The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy

"ent2": 000 ft) while at higher latitudes coniferous forests often dominate."

"rel": this region is typified by montane rain forest (above 3
"ent2": 000 ft) while at higher latitudes coniferous forests often dominate."
column7: "http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_01000342"

"ent1": soil is referred to as regolith
"rel": or loose rock material that lies above the 'solid geology'. Soil is commonly referred to as "earth" or "dirt"; technically
"ent2": the term "dirt" should be restricted to displaced soil.' https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil

"label":
The upper limit of soil is the boundary between soil and air, shallow water, live plants, or plant materials that have not begun to decompose. Areas are not considered to have soil if the surface is permanently covered by water too deep (typically more than 2.5 meters) for the growth of rooted plants.

The lower boundary that separates soil from the nonsoil underneath is most difficult to define. Soil consists of horizons near the Earth's surface that, in contrast to the underlying parent material, have been altered by the interactions of climate, relief, and living organisms over time. Commonly, soil grades at its lower boundary to hard rock or to earthy materials virtually devoid of animals, roots, or other marks of biological activity. For purposes of classification, the lower boundary of soil is arbitrarily set at 200 cm.  Soil taxonomy
"The exact level of the tree line varies with local climate

"rel": this region is typified by montane rain forest (above 3
"ent2": 000 ft) while at higher latitudes coniferous forests often dominate."

Reagents are distinguished from instruments or devices that also participate in scientific techniques by the fact that reagents are chemical or biological in nature and necessarily participate in or have parts that participate in some chemical interaction or reaction during their intended participation in some technique.  By contrast
"ent1": instruments do not participate in a chemical reaction/interaction during the technique.

"label": Reagents are distinguished from study subjects/evaluants in that study subjects and evaluants are that about which conclusions are drawn and knowledge is sought in an investigation - while reagents
"rel": are not.  It should be noted
column5: that reagent and study subject/evaluant roles can be borne by instances of the same type of material entity - but a given instance will realize only one of these roles in the execution of a given assay or technique. For example
column6: taq polymerase can bear a reagent role or an evaluant role.  In a DNA sequencing assay aimed at generating sequence data about some plasmid
column7: the reagent role of the taq polymerase is realized. In an assay to evaluate the quality of the taq polymerase itself
column8: the evaluant/study subject role of the taq is realized
column9: but not the reagent role since the taq is the subject about which data is generated.

"label": In regard to the statement that reagents are 'distinct' from the specified outputs of a technique
"ent1": note that a reagent may be incorporated into a material output of a technique
"rel": as long as the IDENTITY of this output is distinct from that of the bearer of the reagent role.  For example
"ent2": dNTPs input into a PCR are reagents that become part of the material output of this technique
column5: but this output has a new identity (ie that of a 'nucleic acid molecule') that is distinct from the identity of the dNTPs that comprise it.  Similarly
column6: a biotin molecule input into a cell labeling technique are reagents that become part of the specified output
column7: but the identity of the output is that of some modified cell specimen which shares identity with the input unmodified cell specimen
column8: and not with the biotin label. Thus
column9: we see that an important criteria of 'reagent-ness' is that it is a facilitator
column10: and not the primary focus of an investigation or material processing technique (ie not the specified subject/evaluant about which knowledge is sought
column11: or the specified output material of the technique)."
